A very strong starter relic. You aren't guaranteed to proc this every turn, especially with your starter deck only having kindle to light the bolstering ghostflame, but once you start picking up some cheaper attacks and skills, and a power or two, this will very consistently give you 4 block a turn, effectively a better thread and needle, or 2 brass tacks stapled together.

Having that consistent block is really helpful in the early game, so that you can focus more of your energy on dealing damage and ending fights quickly. Even in the later stages of the game, it combines well with shield of night, ghost shield, and floatwork to contribute to a consistent block package. I would not usually recommend swapping this, it's quite strong throughout the whole run, and can be particularly solid in act 1 to help with all 3 elites. You could swap it out if you want to try and gamble on having a better lategame, which does tend to be a problem for hexaghost.

Even after nerfs this is really strong for a starter relic. If you do a boss swap, you might as well just ignore the ghostflames that run because (barring an intensity-focused build) this relic is half their value.
Ghost shield was uncommon at that point, so honestly the rarity switch of those two cards was a buff

I'm not a big fan of this relic.  It gives 4 block on most turns is about the value of a rare relic; which is fine. in act 1 it helps vs nob but is worse vs sentrys, defect and silent (those 2 bosses can force you into turns were you cannot ignite a ghostflame every turn). It is possible to brick and not beable to get this block though, this happens most often with the power ghost flame. As the game progresses this relic's value tends to go down, with the help of ghost shield you don't really need 4 block a turn.
most importantly boss swap is just insane on this character. Nearly ever single hit is good; with really the only super bad one being busted crown
hexaghost is happy to take most "risky" boss relics like choker, dome, coffee dripper, snecko eye and fusion hammer even if they are coming at you at the start of the game
In general hexaghost is only really worried about act 3 and boss swaping helps you prepare more for that act.
I will make you eat your words

wait how does silent make you less likely to activate ghostflames? It adds a single skill to your deck, and if you can get a stoke the flames (which you should be doing if facing silent 1) you can make said skill 0 cost
hard disagree, hexa only really cares about act 1 bosses, repto, defect 2, and IC3 (and Neow, but I rarely fight Neow so I don't have much input here)
oh yeah I forgot to actually say my piece on this one

Like many boss swaps it is giving away immediate power for late game power. I never swap on hexa. Card removals helps a ton because between that and ethereal/afterlife, you can get a REALLY thin deck for fights that slims down to 3 cards from haunted hand (I would do sword/shield of night and the third could be whatever you want, that beats 3/5 act 1 bosses with some pretty easy to get cards.
Whereas hexa doesn't really card for an extra energy that much, with afterlife and premonition as well as a generally pretty cheap card pool
I swear we need to see what the average cost of the card pool is for each character, hexa has gotta be really low
and that doesn't even account for afterlife.
Also hexa doesn't struggle too hard in late game as much as early game, but it sounds like that's just a playstyle difference from me because others say the opposite.

as for the relic itself, it's giving 4 block for doing what you already were going to do. I usually activate at least one ghostflame on 70% of my turns early game and 80% late game, however once again it seems like the average is much higher than me.
So it's thread and needle block
On a character with easy access to blur
Helps a lot in the first few combats
does alright later.
As for the upgraded version it feels a little weird, I rarely take it. you lose 4 block per turn for 1 energy, but I rarely have the need for that energy.

but yknow its ghost shield

thats fair but having an extra energy does let you take expensive cards like infernal form and play draw cards more easily; its still good to have 4 energy on hexaghost although its not as game changing as it is for most characters.

If you get soulburn on the wrong turn you get no damage ageist nemesis which is really bad when it can swing for 45 several times. act 4 elite and boss are also incredibly dangerous for a slow character to fight.

hexaghost can also weirdly struggle ageist darklings of all things because of your random damage killing them when you don't want too. Transcendent can also be pretty scary if your deck doesn't have very many attacks and is just using soulburn.
